top_comment.text:
Concur on the Subaru CVT. The WRX's version is excellent, and that'y why I 
have one.﻿
top_comment.author: Scott Villeneuve

comments.text:
+TestDriveNow.com featuring Drive Time with Steve Hammes I think we've met 
once or twice.
comments.author: Scott Villeneuve
TestDriveNow.com featuring Auto Critic Steve Hammes

top_comment.text:
I'm impressed with the new legacy. I kinda Subaru would bring the looks of 
the dash to more upscale feature but other than that I can't complain about 
subra at all they build some very nice cars recently. Great review as 
always Steve﻿
top_comment.author: Tom De Vito

comments.text:
Your welcome steve sorry the comment is a little hard to read but you get 
the idea it was late when i wrote the comment
comments.author: Tom De Vito
TestDriveNow.com featuring Auto Critic Steve Hammes

top_comment.text: Nice review, Steve. Will you be driving the new Outback next?﻿
top_comment.author: CJ VN

comments.text:
+TestDriveNow.com featuring Drive Time with Steve Hammes Steve -- if that's 
coming, will you be testing the 2.5L Flat-4 or 3.6L Flat-4?  (You could 
also give the 3.6L Flat-6 of the Legacy as well.)
comments.author: Billy Sou

comments.text: That would make sense, but I don't have one on my radar just yet.  Thanks.
comments.author: TestDriveNow.com featuring Auto Critic Steve Hammes

top_comment.text:
I'm torn between the 2015 Hyundai Sonata SE and the 2015 Subaru Legacy 
2.5i. Everyone reviews the higher tier models but they barely ever give us 
the scoop on the base model cars, so it's hard to gauge which gives the 
best bang for buck. BTW, I live in the north east. AWD is a nice plus where 
I live, but not really a must as long as you drive in the snow with a 
little common sense. How do the two compare? Steve? Anyone? And yes, I plan 
to test drive both! Thanks!﻿
top_comment.author: ron bZoom

comments.text:
+ron bZoom I highly recommend splurging and getting the Premium, they just 
offer so much more value than the base level has. In my opinion.
comments.author: orckiller91

comments.text:
+Sam Rosenzweig Yeah, I've been thinking about the Legacy Premium and plan 
on test driving both the 2.5i base and the Premium models. AND it looks 
like the 2015 Legacies are finally here at my local Subaru dealership. For 
$1,700 or so more, it might be worth stepping up from the base to the 
Premium. That is if I don't go with the Sonata. Thanks!
comments.author: ron bZoom

comments.text:
I'm in the same boat as you. However, you get heated cloth seats standard 
and still get the 7 inch touchscreen as shown in this video on the premium 
version of the legacy (one step down from the limited). Still get the 
leather wrapped steering wheel and leather padding on the arm rests too. 
Those plus the AWD are leaning me towards the Legacy over all of the other 
FWD sedans out there
comments.author: Sam Rosenzweig

comments.text:
+noopsky13 Oh I'd say there is considerable resemblance though I suspect 
the Sonata is larger. I've owned 3 Subarus and I'm a bit biased in their 
favor. However, I went with a Hyundai lease a couple of years ago for the 
fuel economy. Now that Subaru has gone CVT, the mpg numbers are almost up 
there with Toyota and Honda without sacrificing the AWD. And it appears 
that the interior and (thank god) infotainment system have been updated 
quite a bit as well. How can I resist coming back? Well... my current 
Hyundai has been quite excellent. My lease ends in March 2015. In the 
meantime, I've tried the 2015 Sonata SE and Limited; both are pretty nice. 
Plus I like this Hyundai dealership. At this time, no 2015 Legacies are 
around in my neck of the woods yet, but will try a few when they are. For 
now, I have to say the new Sonata is kicking butt. But I haven't given up 
on Subaru just yet.
comments.author: ron bZoom

comments.text:
I'd say go for the Subaru. Proven reliability and AWD. Is it just me, or 
does the Subaru and Sonata look alike?
comments.author: Jehu Hairston

top_comment.text:
Abrupt starts is what really irritates me about some cars. I think the CVT 
needs recalibration. ﻿
top_comment.author: igeekone

comments.text:
+Kev erino True...especially in an Eco mode, but this Legacy's 
throttle response is either on or off from a standstill.
comments.author: TestDriveNow.com featuring Auto Critic Steve Hammes

comments.text:
+TestDriveNow.com featuring Drive Time with Steve Hammes Interesting 
because I feel like a lot of newer cars have "deadened" throttle response. 
 Strange that the opposite is true with a car such as this.
comments.author: Kev erino

comments.text: This one would really snap your neck if you weren't careful.
comments.author: TestDriveNow.com featuring Auto Critic Steve Hammes

top_comment.text:
I wouldn't mind having a Subaru Legacy GT for the 2015 model.  They could 
use the 2.0L Turbo Boxer-4 that's either in the BRZ or Forester XT with 
either the 6-speed manual or their heavy duty CVT that both have (now the 
BRZ has more horsepower).  Motor Trend says that the CVT in the Forester XT 
acts similarly to the Porsche PDK dual-clutch, a bold statement.  (Note: 
auto experts -- only Porsche and Subaru are the only auto makers with 
flat/boxer engines).  ﻿
top_comment.author: Billy Sou

comments.text:
The fact that its manual only may have had to do with that, they should've 
offered two transmission choices from the beginning. Outbacks did have XT 
variants in the past and is on the same albeit raise and modified platform 
as the Legacy. I don't see the point in keeping that 3.6 when the FA20DIT 
is sitting right there with a better torque curve and a more usable power 
band, imo. This is particularly evident in the Forester XT which is rather 
quick for a CVT equipped CUV with a turbo-4.
comments.author: LH452

comments.text:
+LH452 I thought about that, however, the Subaru Legacy isn't the best 
seller.  In fact, Subaru sells a great deal more Outbacks than they do 
Legacys.  They had that GT in the 2010 model, but it didn't sell.  Thus, I 
don't think Subaru will put the 2.0L H-4 (FA20), the same engine in the 
BRZ.
comments.author: Billy Sou

comments.text:
The lighter FA20 could actually improve mpgs with the weight lost. Not to 
mention that the flat 6 is also dated now. They should've gotten rid of 
that engine from the get go and switched to the FA20 but it looks like 
it'll be another 3 years before it goes away. The rumor that first came out 
of C&D was that the FA20 or a smaller, more power 3 liter Flat 6 was going 
to replace the 3.6
comments.author: LH452

comments.text:
However, the 3.6L Flat-6 has the similar horsepower at 256, Forester XT 250 
hp.  And now has the CVT instead of the antiquated 5-speed auto.  Thus, 
that's the main reason Subaru probably won't use the 2.0L Turbo Flat-4. 
 And fuel economy would probably similar to the Forester XT.
comments.author: Billy Sou

captions.text:
Here you have the Subaru Legacy. Sales wise,
it’s an also-ran in the midsize or family

sedan segment, if you will; mostly purchased
by northeasterners looking for a traditional

car they can drive confidently on bad roads.
But having spent the week with this all-new

2015 Legacy, I’d say it’s the most mainstream
vehicle Subaru has ever produced and that’ll

resonate with a broader audience.Subaru is
a brand on fire. The champion of all-wheel

drive and an active lifestyle continues its
push from the backwoods into suburbia. They

know they’ve got the camping, dog-loving
crowd wrapped around their tires but this

sixth-generation Legacy is all about expanding
appeal. Though the conservative styling is

completely anonymous, it’s not ugly and
for Subaru that’s a step in the right direction.

It clearly bears a resemblance to the Ford
Taurus. Its body size has hardly changed,

but there’s more room inside where it counts,
like back here. Leg room is right up there

near the top of the midsize segment and the
trunk’s 15 cubic feet is equally competitive.

So the Legacy’s undersized criticisms are
now in the past.Subaru’s interiors typically

feel cheap, which is why I’m pleasantly
surprised by the highly cushioned, soft-leather

touch points for your arms. And though its
design won’t wow anybody, the attention

to detail and overall quality feels several
notches up.When shopping Legacy, you can choose

from 4 models and this here is the 2.5i Limited
– the top ranking 4-cylinder car with a

starting MSRP of $27,290. There’s one big
option package in here which adds a moonroof,

keyless access with push button start, a navigation
system integrated into the new Starlink touchscreen

and the upgraded EyeSight driver assist system.
Using new color stereo cameras, EyeSight bundles

Adaptive Cruise Control, Pre-Collision Braking,
Lane Departure Warning and the never before

seen Steering Responsive Fog Lights – a
poor man’s adaptive headlights, of sorts;

providing enhanced illumination in turns by
activating them independently when the fog

lights are in their off position. Combine
those safety perks with a new rear radar system,

and you’ve also got Rear Vehicle Detection,
Blind Spot Detection, Lane Change Assist and

Rear Cross Traffic Alert. And there’re new
front seat-cushion airbags to boot, helping

keep occupants in place in a frontal collision.You
often hear criticisms about the dreaded CVT

or continuously variable transmission but
not in here. Subaru’s Lineartronic version

in this Legacy is likely the best in the industry
by feeling most like a traditional automatic.

And in general, this car feels very much the
part of a driver’s car. The steering has

a very accurate touch with a good sense of
straight ahead, the Boxer engine’s responsiveness

has been spread across a broader RPM range,
and the all-wheel drive system now incorporates

torque vectoring for improved handling. It
is indeed a fun car to have on the back roads.

But if there is but one problem it’s that
the Legacy refuses to start off smoothly…I

don’t care how gentle you are in applying
the gas takeoff is always a bit abrupt.The

2.5-liter engine’s 175 horsepower is a smidge
higher than before but if it’s speed you’re

after the 3.6-liter engine awaits – because
the Legacy is likely the slowest to 60mph

in the class, taking almost 9 seconds. It
feels much quicker though once you’re in

the midrange. The double wishbone rear suspension
adds to the nimbleness but the Legacy’s

ride quality isn’t as forgiving as some
other new entries I’ve driven recently.

With an aluminum hood and Active Grille Shutters
among other efficiencies, gas mileage has

improved from 27mpg to 30mpg combined and
my own results show 31mpg – stellar for

an all-wheel drive car. But for those of you
searching for the stick shift option – sorry,

it’s the CVT or the highway this time around.The
Legacy has matured. It’s quieter and feels

more substantial. Quality is improved, it’s
more spacious and though the GT model is no

longer this 2.5i Limited always gave me a
reason to want to take the road less traveled.

MSRP as tested is $30,580 – a strong price
point for a Subaru better armed to compete
with the heavy hitters.

title: 2015 Subaru Legacy - TestDriveNow.com Review by Auto Critic Steve Hammes
